latency.title: Invisible Latency
latency.description: Speedtests measure speed, not consistency. A 100ms micro-cut (Packet Loss) is fatal for you.

jitter.title: Critical Jitter
jitter.description: Signal variance (Jitter). The mathematical cause of robotic voices and unexplained lags.

bufferbloat.title: Bufferbloat
bufferbloat.description: When your router chokes. A hardware bottleneck only a precise audit can reveal.

seo1.title: WHY YOU LAG DESPITE FIBER
seo1.p1: Your ISP sells you '1 Gbps'. You pay. You still lag.
seo1.p2: The problem isn't SPEED. It's STABILITY.
seo1.p3: A classic speedtest takes a photo. We film in 4K.
seo1.highlight: Stability Protocol measures JITTER (invisible micro-cuts) that Speedtest.net ignores. If your ping jumps from 15ms to 80ms, that's a lag spike. We detect it. They don't.
seo1.result: Result: You FINALLY know if the problem comes from:
seo1.cta: Test for 30 seconds. No bullshit marketing.

seo2.fix_intro: Run the test. Watch the curve in real time.
fix_steps: Replace Cat 5 Ethernet cable with Cat 8
seo2.fix_result: If the curve smooths out = you just gained 20ms without changing your plan.
seo2.fix_outro: That's what we call "stabilizing the signal".
seo2.mobile_subtitle: THE NETWORK IS A PHYSICS PROBLEM
seo2.mobile_physics: Concrete blocks. Waves bounce. Microwaves interfere.
seo2.mobile_result: Curve turns green? You found your "Zero Point". Bookmark that spot.
seo2.mobile_outro: We've stabilized 4G connections to 12ms jitter just by changing rooms.

seo3.title: HOW IT WORKS (Without the Bullshit)
seo3.bad_desc: Takes 3 readings, averages them, tells you "GG".
seo3.good_desc: Takes 300 readings, detects micro-cuts, shows you the raw truth.
seo3.filter: We use a Savitzky-Golay filter (Master-level mathematics) to separate NOISE from the real SIGNAL.
seo3.use_case_intro: If your score is high here, your connection will hold under any critical load:

dashboard.warning: ISPs sell you '1 Gbps'. It's marketing. For Gaming, speed is worthless without STABILITY.
dashboard.mission: We built this tool for one reason: Stop the waste. Too many players buy overpriced routers when simple software tweaks would suffice.

rules.title: OUR GOLDEN RULE:
rules.one: 1. SOFTWARE FIRST: Check Drivers, QoS, DNS. It's free.
rules.two: 2. HARDWARE LAST: If physics is the cause, only then do we recommend specific gear.

jitter.title: Jitter
jitter.summary: The variance in latency time. The #1 enemy of competitive gaming.
jitter.intro: Jitter is not about speed — it's about stability. It's the variation in latency (Ping) between each data packet.
jitter.block_content: Imagine a train that should arrive every 10 minutes. If the first arrives at 10:00, the second at 10:20, and the third at 10:21... the average is fine, but the service is unusable. That's Jitter.
jitter.section_title: Why is it fatal for Gaming?
jitter.section_intro: In a competitive game (Valorant, CS2, LoL), the server predicts your position. If your packets arrive irregularly (high Jitter), the server no longer knows where you are. Result:
section_items: Rubberbanding: You move forward, then get teleported back.
Desync: You shoot an enemy, but the server rejects the shot.
Robotic Voice: On Discord, voice packets arrive out of order.
jitter.diag_content:
1. Switch to Ethernet (Cable): WiFi is the #1 cause of Jitter (interference).
2. Enable QoS: On your router, prioritize Gaming traffic.
3. Change DNS: Sometimes bad routing creates instability.
jitter.cta_desc: Classic speedtests smooth out results and hide Jitter. Use our professional tool to measure the real variance.
jitter.content: Jitter is the variance in time delay between data packets over a network. High jitter causes instability in gaming and voice calls.

bufferbloat.title: Bufferbloat
bufferbloat.summary: When your router chokes under load. The cause of lag when someone watches Netflix.
bufferbloat.intro: Bufferbloat is the hidden increase in your ping when your connection is fully used (download or streaming). It's like trying to talk in a crowded room.
bufferbloat.block_content: Everything is fine (20ms ping). Suddenly, someone starts a 4K video or a network update. Your ping instantly jumps to 400ms. That's Bufferbloat.
bufferbloat.section_intro: Modern routers have too much "buffer memory" (Buffer). They store packets in a queue instead of processing them fast. Result: a huge queue builds up, and your gaming packets get stuck behind the download.
bufferbloat.diag_content:
The real solution isn't "more bandwidth" — it's better queue management.
1. Limit bandwidth: Cap your connection at 95% of max capacity to prevent the buffer from filling.
2. Enable SQM / QoS: On high-end routers (Asus Merlin, OpenWRT), SQM prioritizes small packets (Gaming/Voice) over large ones (Downloads).
bufferbloat.cta_desc: Our tool simulates intense network load to see if your router collapses. Do you score A+ or F?
bufferbloat.content: Bufferbloat occurs when a router buffers too much data, creating artificial latency. It's a hardware-level bottleneck.

packet_loss.title: Packet Loss
packet_loss.summary: Data lost in transit. Causes teleportation effects and disconnections.
packet_loss.intro: Packet Loss occurs when part of the data you send (shots, movements) never reaches the server. It's the digital "black hole".
packet_loss.block_content: Unlike high Ping (everything is slow), Packet Loss creates ruptures. You're running, and suddenly you're snapped 3 meters back. Why? Because the server never received the "I'm moving" message and resets you to your last known position.
section_items: Unstable WiFi: Signal passing through walls = packet loss.
Damaged Ethernet cable: A pinched cable or wrong category (old Cat 5).
Saturated ISP: The connection node in your neighborhood is full.
packet_loss.diag_content: Open a command prompt (CMD) and type `ping google.com -n 100`. If you see "Request timed out", you have Packet Loss.
packet_loss.diag_note: For Gaming, even 1% loss is unacceptable.
packet_loss.cta_desc: Our test analyzes signal continuity over 10 seconds to detect micro-cuts invisible to classic speedtests.
packet_loss.content: Packet loss happens when data units fail to reach their destination. It results in 'teleporting' or disconnected sessions.
